docs.lead_paragraph: With good intentions and bright advisers, Congress overwhelming passed legislation in 1988 that would insure the elderly against catastrophic medical expenses, including crushing drug costs. But affluent retirees quickly concluded that they were being asked to pay for something that their employers already gave. They rose in revolt. Congress repealed the legislation within months.

headline.main: Some Experts Foresee Revolt by Elderly Over Drug Benefits
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: RETIREE CARE

docs.abstract: Some experts expect revolt over Medicare bill just approved by Congress if large employers drop drug benefits for retirees once federal government establishes its own; 11 million retirees now enjoy private drug benefits that are more generous than what government will provide; legislation provides billions of dollars in tax incentives to discourage employers from dropping benefits, but that may not be enough for some employers (M)
docs.snippet: With good intentions and bright advisers, Congress overwhelming passed legislation in 1988 that would insure the elderly against catastrophic medical expenses, including crushing drug costs.    But affluent retirees quickly concluded that they were...

docs.lead_paragraph: William D. Novelli, the chief executive of AARP, sat in his downtown Washington office on Tuesday, still glowing from the Senate's passage of prescription-drug legislation that his group had endorsed, and slid a copy of the glossy AARP magazine across a mahogany table. The actress Lauren Hutton was on the cover, along with blurbs for stories about ''where to find love'' and ''amazing new sex drugs.'' The message was clear. ''Boomers,'' Mr. Novelli declared, ''are the future of the AARP.''

headline.main: AARP Support Came as Group Grew 'Younger'
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: THE ENDORSMENT

docs.abstract: Growing ranks of baby boomers in AARP, retiree lobby, is behind organization's decision to endorse Republican-backed Medicare bill, thus ensuring its passage; AARP has moved aggressively to expand its membership by focusing on people 45 and older, and polls and focus groups have indicated that boomers would support experiment with private competition in government-run Medicare program -- a contentious provision that many elderly people, AARP's traditional constituency, bitterly oppose; critics question just who AARP represents and whether interests of elderly are really being served; some Democrats accuse AARP of endorsing bill to advance its insurance business, a charge AARP officials strongly deny; photo (M)
docs.snippet: William D. Novelli, the chief executive of AARP, sat in his downtown Washington office on Tuesday, still glowing from the Senate's passage of prescription-drug legislation that his group had endorsed, and slid a copy of the glossy AARP magazine...

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and MILT FREUDENHEIM

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans said yesterday that it had dropped its demands that psychotherapists refund fees based on the company's claim that the therapists' notes of client sessions were inadequate. In return, the New York State Psychiatric Association, the American Psychiatric Association and the New York State Society for Clinical Social Work have agreed to work with Oxford to develop uniform standards for such record-keeping.

headline.main: Insurer Backs Off on Call For Refund of Therapy Fees

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans drops call for refunds from psychotherapists and social workers who it had audited for allegedly inadequate note-taking; New York State Psychiatric Association and New York State Society for Clinical Social Work will in turn develop higher standards of record-keeping concerning bills (M)

keywords.value: NEW YORK STATE SOCIETY FOR CLINICAL SOCIAL WORK

docs.lead_paragraph: As grand piano No. K0862 was being wheeled from workbench to workbench at the Steinway & Sons factory in Queens in late September, the workers had two schedules in mind: the one that they did not talk about much, and the one that had them buzzing. The first was the schedule for finishing No. K0862, which was just another piano making its way through a factory with a quota of 10 a day. The second schedule, talked about at lunchtime and on coffee breaks, was the one for negotiating a union contract.

headline.main: INVENTION FOR 900 HANDS: 'Our Core Business'; At Steinway, It's Hammer Time

docs.abstract: Invention for 900 Hands column, sixth in series following one Steinway concert grand piano through production, discusses Steinway's embattled infrastructure, downgrade by Standard & Poor's, steep decline in sales and pending union negotiations; photos (L)

headline.main: Medicare Reform: Who Wins and Loses

docs.abstract: Summary of which groups are regarded as winners and which are losers in Medicare reform legislation: impact on taxpayers, low-income elderly, affluent retirees, retiree health plans, AARP, political parties and various other groups discussed (M)

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM AND ROBIN TONER

docs.lead_paragraph: In a debate yesterday in Des Moines, the Democratic presidential candidates all addressed the issue of prescription drug coverage for Medicare recipients. All the candidates except Senator Joseph I. Lieberman were present. SENATOR JOHN KERRY -- ''I believe what's going to happen is you're going to find seniors as angry with this as they were with the catastrophic health insurance when we passed it in the 1980's and then had to take it back. This represents a special-interest giveaway. And the headlines you saw in the newspapers the last days said, ''Drug companies win.'' Now, if the drug companies win, who's losing? It's the seniors in America.''
docs.abstract: Brief excerpts from comments by Democratic presidential aspirants at debate in Des Moines

docs.lead_paragraph: Its passage was never going to be a sure thing, or even, at times, a likely one. For six years Congress had tried, and failed, to reach agreement on legislation overhauling Medicare and adding prescription drug benefits for the 40 million elderly and disabled Americans in the program. But the drive always foundered on ideological divisions over the future of the program. On a profound mistrust between the parties. On the sheer political complexity of navigating legislation through a minefield of powerful interest groups.

headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: NEWS ANALYSIS

docs.abstract: News analysis of bill to create Medicare prescription drug benefit, now set to become law after foundering for years on ideological differences; divisions are seen in brutally polarized votes but seem overwhelmed by hunger for politically important deal; Republican Congressional leaders, Pres Bush, powerful elderly lobby and just enough Democrats align to push through vast new bill; AARP endorsement also seen key (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After 12 years as a public health nurse, I received my first report of pertussis, or whooping cough, last year. I knew very little about it then, but by the time I was finished with my investigations I knew the first names of all the communicable disease experts at the state level. Pertussis is a potentially deadly contagious disease that children are now vaccinated against beginning at 2 months and followed by a series of boosters.
docs.abstract: Christine Contillo Cases column describes re-emergence of pertussis, or whooping cough, and how factors such as patient privacy laws and insurance restrictions lead to diagnostic roadblocks and inadequate treatments (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a fourth-year medical student, Jeffrey Lawler listens -- really listens -- as his patients run through their lists of physical complaints. When he touches a scar or feels for bumps, lumps or growths, he directs all of his focus into his hands, moving his fingertips slowly over skin, tissue and bone, occasionally pressing and prodding gently. A talking blood pressure cuff recites readings in an automated voice, and a nurse or fellow medical student lets Mr. Lawler know that a patient's temperature is hovering around 100.

headline.main: Barriers Toppling for Disabled Medical Students

docs.abstract: Since enactment of 1990 Americans With Disabilities Act, more disabled individuals are considering medical school as viable career path; fourth-year medical student Jeffrey Lawler, who has disease retinitis pigmentosa, which has left him legally blind since 1993, describes personal challenges and advantages in working with patients; holds disability makes him more empathetic physician; concerns about maintaining medical standards and patient safety discussed; Physician Insurers Assn of America reports no difference in insuring doctors who are disabled; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate beat back two major challenges on Monday to a bill that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare. The votes cleared the way for Congress to approve the biggest changes in the program since it was created in 1965 as a cornerstone of the Great Society. The Republican victory on Medicare was partly offset when Senate leaders abandoned efforts to pass an energy bill that was second only to Medicare as a priority for the Bush administration and the Republican-controlled Congress. [A20.]

headline.main: SENATE REMOVES TWO ROADBLOCKS TO DRUG BENEFIT
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Senate Republican leadership beats back two major challenges to bill that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, clearing away for biggest changes in program since it began in 1965; majority, with some Democratic support, breaks filibuster led by Edward Kennedy and then defeats budget challenge to House-passed measure that Pres Bush hopes to use in re-election campaign; eight of nine Democratic challengers see threat to Medicare and boon to special interests; Senate leader Bill Frist hails votes; photos; table; AARP endorsement is seen turning point (M)
